message: There seems a dizzying array of new frameworks for JS available now for building rich client side apps.  We're just digging into backbone.js now as it looks really clean and solves a common problem simply.
I've heard good things about it, though no direct experience.
I would say that if you're evaluating them, you should consider looking into sproutcore.
Anyone with experience with angular as an alternative?
Thx.
Also, on the mobile side, we're trying out jQuery mobile (but have also looked at JQTouch and Sencha Touch).
Any Coffeescript users out there? Anything to report when building complex client-side applications?
Sproutcore: I've heard really good things, but haven't used it directly.
@drhayes: I've used CoffeeScript for several projects now and really like it.  Keeps the code from getting too crazy when doing more than generic jQuery stuff.
It gives you just enough structure to keep your code organized while still giving you a lot of flexibility.
I've personally been quite satisfied with Backbone.js. I've built 4 applications with it so far and I picked it over others, like Sproutcore because of the the *tiny* comparative size.
I wrote a blog post about it that hit the front page of HN. Here's the link: http://andyet.net/blog/2010/oct/29/building-a-single-page-app-with-backbonejs-undersc/
Henrik, that post helped me build my first couple Backbone apps. Thanks.
@tswicegood Ah, okay, great. I'm digging a little deeper into https://github.com/stephank/orona/ to see a large Coffeescript app in the wild. Any others that you know of?
@HenrikJoreteg awesome read man, got me excited to play around with it
i haven't look at backbone yet but i love everything jeremy does
@HenrikJoreteg that is one good looking blog
@canaste  @HenrikJoreteg yes, this article is great and very inspirative. backbone.js is cool.
I wanna give this a try: http://jonobr1.github.com/gui-dat/
I really appreciate the rigor that backbone forces me to have, more than once its made things that I made too complicated much simpler and easier to work with
@HenrikJoreteg Great post, I'll definitly give a shot at backbone.js very soon
@tbeseda awesome, glad it helped.
@defunkt, yeah Jeremy's the man.

but do I understand it right? There is no way to make your app working without JS and using backbone.js? Like, you can't "enhance" a page with backbone.js – you build the logic with backbone? Or is there a way to still have your content accessible to non-js agents?
An other framework: http://knockoutjs.com/ really easy to use and test. Didn't try backbone yet though.
@gryzzly i think you are correct. if the browser doesn't run js, backbone.js won't help you

I'm currently building a (hopefully really awesome) feed reader with backbone.js. I'm new to serious client side scripting (horrible at design, coming from building django and flask webapps), but I like backbone a lot
@kastner gui-dat looks interesting for some smaller projects ... thanks!
hi
@HenrikJoreteg yeah thanks for the article

+1 for CoffeeScript and Backbone.js stack.  Eventually you may find yourself looking for a nice way to do dependency management / file organization /  concatenation.  The 'requisition' project seems to be on the right track: https://github.com/feisty/requisition
